analytic.title: D R A F T

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Play is important in many cultures and species, but the basic motivations behind play remain unclear. In two preregistered experiments, we presented 5-to-10-year-old children (n = 124) with a novel game. We compared their choices about how to best configure the game when either playing for fun or playing to win, exploring: 1) how sensitive children are to the factors that are most relevant for playing to win; and 2) how their preferences when playing for fun relates to their preferences when playing to win. We found that for "win-relevant" features, children chose easier settings when playing to win than when playing for fun. By contrast, for "win-irrelevant" features, children generally preferred similar settings across conditions. Children also judged "win-relevant" factors as more important to winning than "win-irrelevant" factors, and judged both as irrelevant to having fun. These results suggest that playing to win and playing for fun are distinct motivational contexts to which children can appropriately adapt their decisions during play.

div.head: D R A F T Introduction
div.p: Many creatures play. Lion cubs mock-hunt, otters juggle rocks, dolphins blow bubbles to swim through, and human children spend hours building block towers, swarming playgrounds, and exploring for dinosaurs, dragons, and aliens. In addition to humans (Groos, 1901;Piaget, 1951) and other mammals (Groos, 1911;Spinka et al., 2001), play can also be found in many birds, reptiles, fish, and perhaps even insects (Burghardt, 2005(Burghardt, , 2015Galpayage et al., 2022). Moreover, human play takes on many forms (Opie & Opie, 1960;Whitebread et al., 2017), appears across a wide variety of human cultures (Edwards, 2000;Gaskins et al., 2007;Samuelsson & Fleer, 2008), and is evident across the historical record (Chudacoff, 2007;De Maret & Sidéra, 2015;Decker, 1992;S. E. Kidd, 2019;Sidéra & Vornicu, 2016).

Despite its prevalence, play remains difficult to characterize. It is the sort of behavior that people readily recognize, and its utility can be characterized in specific contexts. However, it has been difficult to provide a general theoretical account of play. Descriptive accounts generally agree that play is: structured; often repetitive; most common in youth; most likely when individuals are healthy, relaxed, or bored; irrelevant to immediate survival; and thus intrinsically motivated (Burghardt, 2010). Despite these shared features, play manifests in many different behaviors, each with different benefits for development: rough and tumble play leads to more social bonding (Pellis & Pellis, 2007); pretend play improves counterfactual inference (Buchsbaum et al., 2012;Wente et al., 2022); exploratory play leads to discoveries about causal structure (Bonawitz et al., 2012;Schulz & Bonawitz, 2007); and guided play often improves educational outcomes (Skene et al., 2022;Weisberg et al., 2013Weisberg et al., , 2016Yu et al., 2018).
Due to the diversity of play behaviors, theoretical accounts often aim to explain only particular kinds of play (Chu & Schulz, 2020;Rubin et al., 1983;Zosh et al., 2018).

Because the theoretical understanding of play is so fractured, many basic questions about play remain unanswered. One prominent such question has to do with the motivations underlying play, which remain obscure. While nearly all theories of play assume that children are motivated by an intrinsic desire to "have fun", very little work has characterized "fun" or examined how competing extrinsic factors may D R A F T interact with the pursuit of fun in play. Here, we investigate the rewards and motivations underlying play by using a game design task in which children are prompted to manipulate the features of a game to make it more appropriate either for playing for fun (i.e. optimizing for intrinsic, self-motivated reward), or playing to win (i.e. optimizing for extrinsic, externally-defined reward) (Ryan & Deci, 2020). Children's decisions in this task thus provide a window onto the ways that changes in motivation affect goal selection during play. Using this paradigm, we consider the following two questions. First, we ask how sensitive children are to the task features that are most relevant for playing to win. Second, we use this improved understanding of playing to win to ask how the motivations underlying playing for fun differ (if at all) from those underlying playing to win. These questions are important because they may shed light on one of the fundamental unknowns regarding play: what motivates agents to play in the first place.

We built our paradigm around structured game play for two reasons. First, rule-based games are a significant part of play for school-aged children (Opie & Opie, 1960;Taylor, 1999). Games are thus part of what theories of play need to explain, and any theory of play should apply to them. Second, games are a particularly good place to look for systematic variation between different motivations to play. Unlike the complex, improvisational, and highly varied forms of pretense, motor, and exploratory play that are common in preschoolers, game playing derives structure from the requirement to follow the rules of the game itself (whether well-established or invented spontaneously). Games often come with systems of reward and punishment and, critically, clear conditions for winning. These structural features of games have recently been explained as a way for players to explore various kinds of agency-different constellations of goals, abilities, and constraints-in a relatively controlled environment (Nguyen, 2020).

What is important for our purposes is that the relatively restricted degrees of freedom inherent to structured games enable us to more directly assess children's decision-making given different motivational contexts, rather than trying to infer it from spontaneous behavior.

Our first research question builds on existing work to better understand how sensitive children are to the task features that are most relevant for playing to win. Motivations lie on a continuum from those which are purely extrinsic to an individual to those which are purely intrinsic (Ryan & Deci, 2020). The

div.head: D R A F T
div.p: introduction of extrinsic motivators can lead to lower intrinsic motivation and, in some situations, reduce the performance they are intended to reward (Ryan & Koestner, 1999;cf. Cameron et al., 2001). For example, one study prompted sixth graders to choose a series of anagrams to solve. When the task was framed as an assignment graded based on performance rather than as an ungraded educational game, children chose less challenging anagrams and showed fewer signs of enjoying them (Harter, 1978). It remains unclear, however, to what extent the motivation to win leads children to selectively manipulate task difficulty as compared to other aspects of the task which may have no bearing on winning.

By better characterizing how children understand playing to win, we can then consider our second question-namely, how the motivations underlying playing for fun might differ from those underlying playing to win. One possibility is that playing for fun ultimately is playing to win: maximizing fun is merely maximizing the likelihood of winning. This possibility might seem unlikely, however, as children seem to challenge themselves more when playing without performance pressure than when participating in the same activity with performance pressure (Harter, 1978). Similarly, optimal challenge (e.g. playing a moderately superior opponent in chess) strongly predicts task enjoyment, even more so than skill, when adults are intrinsically motivated and goal-directed (Abuhamdeh & Csikszentmihalyi, 2012). A second possibility is that playing for fun is a kind of playing to win that relies on maximizing success for a specific type of goal or metric, such as earning a high score or setting a personal record. A third possibility is that playing for fun is different from playing to win. That is, playing for fun may change the relative significance of motivations other than winning, such as: information gain, mastery, autonomy, meaning-seeking, social connection, self-signaling, novelty, visceral pleasure, and aesthetic experience (Berridge & Kringelbach, 2015;Chater & Loewenstein, 2016;Churchland, 2018;Deci & Ryan, 1980;Fishbach & Woolley, 2022;Haber et al., 2018;C. Kidd & Hayden, 2015;Loewenstein, 1999;Oudeyer et al., 2007;Ryan & Deci, 2017;Skov, 2019;Stanley & Lehman, 2015;Wigfield et al., 2021;Wilson et al., 2021). Changes in motivation might effectively downweight winning or, equivalently, upweight other motivations. By contrasting children's choices when playing for fun and playing to win, we can better understand the relationship between these two types of play.

div.head: D R A F T
div.p: To address these questions, we contrasted children's choices about how to set up exactly the same game when it was framed in a way that emphasized playing for fun (Fun, i.e. "have as much fun as you can"), or instead focused on playing to win (Win, i.e. "win stickers"). In our activity, "Beach Bowling" (Fig. 1a), participants try to knock down blocks by throwing bean bags and batons. We introduced children to eight ways of changing the task. Critically, some changes were win-relevant and others were win-irrelevant. Win-relevant changes affect the likelihood of success (e.g. throwing distance), while win-irrelevant changes did not (e.g. color of batons): they instead varied dimensions commonly associated with play, such as novelty, randomness, autonomy, and dressing up as a different character. We then asked children how to best design Beach Bowling either for winning stickers or for having fun by adjusting these variables. We also collected participants' explicit judgments about how important each feature was in achieving these ends. This allowed us to test both how sensitive children are to the features that matter for playing to win and also in what ways playing for fun might go beyond playing to win. This game design paradigm provides a tractable way to reveal whether and how changes in motivation affect the fine-grained details of goal and action selection. We tested a broad age range of young children (i.e. 5-10 years old) to identify possible developmental changes. In particular, we consider the possibility that younger children care less about difficulty or struggle to assess difficulty, perhaps overestimating their abilities (Chu & Schulz, 2023b;Zhang et al., 2023).

Using this approach, our primary focus is to better understand children's motivations during play-particularly to better characterize children's motivations when playing for fun by contrasting it with playing to win. We begin, however, by examining their understanding of playing to win. We expect that if children can reason selectively and explicitly about the factors that influence the probability of winning, then they will: 1) choose easier settings for win-relevant variables in the Win Condition than in the Fun condition; and 2) judge win-relevant variables as more important than win-irrelevant variables in the Win Condition. By contrast, if their judgments are largely implicit, they may still choose easier win-relevant settings when playing to win but may not be able to judge these variables as more important than win-irrelevant variables. Finally, if they choose equivalent win-relevant settings and judge them equally D R A F T important in both conditions, this would provide evidence either that they do not understand which factors affect the probability of winning or that playing for fun is perhaps the same thing as playing to win. This latter hypothesis would be further strengthened if children also set win-irrelevant variables equivalently and judge them as similarly important across conditions. By contrast, differences across conditions, particularly in judgments about which variables matter, would provide evidence that playing for fun differs from playing to win in important ways.

We conducted two preregistered experiments to test these hypotheses. In Experiment 1, children configured each aspect of the game for both the Win and the Fun Conditions. We found that for win-relevant features, children chose easier settings during the Win Condition than during the Fun Condition. Similarly, children also chose lower settings for two of four win-irrelevant features. In addition, children judged that win-relevant variables mattered in the Win Condition but that no variables mattered in the Fun Condition. To test if these findings result from an artificial contrast between conditions due to a within-subjects design, Experiment 2 assigned each child to only one condition.

Replicating Experiment 1, we found that children chose significantly easier settings for win-relevant variables during the Win Condition than during the Fun Condition. By contrast, children chose similar settings for win-irrelevant variables across conditions, even though these variables manipulate dimensions commonly associated with play. We also found that children judged win-relevant variables as more important than win-irrelevant variables in the Win Condition but judged both kinds as equally irrelevant in the Fun condition. These results suggest that children are able to explicitly reason about which features of a task affect the likelihood of winning and set them appropriately both when playing to win and when playing for fun. They also show that playing for fun does in fact differ from playing to win in that children make different decisions under the two conditions and judge the importance of win-relevant variables differently across conditions.

div.head: D R A F T Experiment 1
div.p: In Experiment 1, we asked children how to best configure a novel activity under two conditions: Win and Fun. We used a within-subjects design: each participant answered the same questions about both conditions, with condition order counterbalanced across participants.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Participants were n = 80 English-speaking children (45 female) aged 5-10 years (M age = 7.68, SD = 1.41) from summer camps and children's museums in a major US city. Condition order was counterbalanced (n=40 Win-first and n=40 Fun-first), and we aimed to sample across the age range by recruiting similar numbers of younger 5-7-year-olds (n=43) and older 8-10-year-olds (n=37). Demographic data such as ethnicity were not collected, although museum visitor statistics suggest a predominantly White (49%) and Asian (17%) sample. The sample size was chosen to yield 80% power to detect a medium difference between the Win and Fun conditions, based on an estimate from pilot data collected with n = 34 participants. Five additional children were excluded for incomplete responses (n=2) or experimenter error (n=3).

div.head: Task design and materials
div.p: In our "Beach Bowling" activity, participants tossed bean bags and batons to knock down blocks on a rectangular court (2.7 meters long x 1.7 meters wide). Children modified the activity by setting eight variables: four win-relevant variables that affected the likelihood of knocking down blocks, and four win-irrelevant variables that did not affect game difficulty but are common features of children's everyday play (e.g. colorful objects, dressing up, rolling dice, spinning a wheel), emphasizing lighthearted engagement and autonomy of choice (Mukherjee et al., 2023). Each variable could be set at one of three possible values (e.g. 1, 2, or 3 sharks to avoid); win-relevant variables all included one "easy", "medium", and "hard" value, determined by pilot testing. Fig. 1a shows the activity and possible settings for each variable; see Supplemental Materials: A for additional details.

div.head: D R A F T Procedure
div.p: Our procedure complies with all relevant ethical regulations and was approved by the Committee for the Protection of Human Subjects at [omitted for peer review] where the study was conducted. Participants and/or guardians provided informed consent. Two experimenters tested children in an outdoor area. The primary experimenter introduced children to the task and then asked about their game design preferences ( Fig. 1b; see full script at https://osf.io/uz49n?view_only=3fcdc7408cd14e1a91aa52da8e9ba94e). where participants toss batons from different positions on the yellow runway. Participants earn points for knocking down rectangular blocks, but incur penalties for landing batons inside the sharks. Participants can modify the game along four Win-Relevant variables (#1-4, in red) which affect task difficulty, and four Win-Irrelevant variables (#5-8, in blue) which do not affect task difficulty. Each variable offers three possible settings, listed low to high. (B) Overall protocol for Experiment 1 (E1) and Experiment 2 (E2). An experimenter introduces the Beach Bowling task and two conditions: to win stickers (WIN) or have as much fun as possible (FUN). Then, participants answer three questions about each variable. Condition was manipulated within-subjects in Experiment 1, but between-subjects in Experiment 2.

div.head: D R A F T
div.p: Introduction Phase. First, Experimenter 1 described Beach Bowling as an activity where "we try to knock down some blocks". Children then watched Experimenter 2 demonstrate Beach Bowling while Experimenter 1 narrated their actions. Experimenter 2 made three tosses, making sure to always land one bean bag in a shark's mouth as Experimenter 1 commented, "Uh oh! Not good… Now they can't get it back!" Next, Experimenter 1 introduced the two game conditions (Win and Fun), saying (critical manipulations underlined): "Now that you know what it looks like to play Beach Bowling, let me tell you something. There are actually two different ways to play this game. One way to play this game is to play to win stickers. If we play to win stickers, then the rule is that you need to knock down all six blocks in order to get some stickers. If you don't knock down all six blocks, then you don't get any stickers at all.

The other way to play this game is just for fun. If we play for fun, there are no prizes for knocking down the blocks, and the rule is that you need to have as much fun as possible." For each variable, children first learned about the three choices. The choices were presented in either randomized order (for win-irrelevant variables) or in increasing order of difficulty (for win-relevant variables). Because we can clearly identify the impact a change is likely to have on winning, all win-relevant choices were described as "easy," "medium," and "hard," so that children did not need to make this inference themselves. We cannot do the same for win-irrelevant choices, as they do not affect the likelihood of winning (by design), and we do not know what exactly children are optimizing for when they seek to have fun. Higher settings for these dimensions are intended to provide more of the feature associated with the dimension (e.g. the highest setting of randomness injects more randomness into the game than the middle setting, which injects more than the lowest setting), but we do not claim that
children should optimize them in a given direction. We therefore opted not to bias children's judgments by labeling the win-irrelevant choices in any particular way.

After the variable was introduced, children answered three questions in fixed order. We prefaced every question with a reminder of the relevant condition, saying, "If you were playing to make sure that you [knock down all the blocks to win stickers / have as much fun as possible]..." First, Experimenter 1 asked children whether that variable "mattered" for the condition (i.e. for having fun or knocking down blocks). Next, Experimenter 1 asked for children's first preference. Options were presented in the same order as when first introduced. Finally, Experimenter 1 prompted children for their preference among the remaining two options. These three questions were then repeated for the other condition (Win or Fun), before moving to the next variable.

The entire sequence (variable introduction and six questions) was repeated for the remaining variables such that children answered 48 questions in total. The order of the variables was randomized for each participant by shuffling the cue cards, and children were randomly assigned to always receive either Win or Fun questions first (Supplemental Materials: B analyzes condition order effects). After these questions, Experimenter 1 concluded the procedure by asking whether children would rather play for fun, or try to win.

div.head: Results
div.p: To understand the effect of motivation context on task selection, we examined three aspects of children's decisions. First, we examined children's preferred game settings. Second, we examined which variables
children explicitly judged to be important. Finally, as an exploratory analysis, we examined correlations between children's preferred game settings and these importance judgments.
We initially preregistered a series of ANOVAs and pairwise t-tests to examine how children's choices varied by condition, and how the effect of condition might be moderated by variable type and age.

However, after data collection, we realized that taking a mixed effects regression approach would more appropriately account for the correlational structure in our repeated measures design. This change in analytical method resulted in no change to conclusions. Thus, for each analysis below, we first report the best fit model and any significant model-estimated coefficients. We then report pre-registered tests on the raw data, as well as descriptive statistics, to aid in interpreting the regression coefficients.
We fit models using the lme4 R package (Bates, 2024). For models including age as a covariate, we first transformed age (in months) into z-scores to aid model convergence.

div.head: Game Setting Choices
div.p: Our primary research questions center on whether participants will choose different game settings when prompted to try to win versus play for fun. For each variable, we assigned one point for choosing the lowest or easiest setting and three points for the highest or hardest setting. For win-relevant variables, a higher score indicates a preference for more difficult challenges. For win-irrelevant variables, a higher score indicates a preference for greater amounts of autonomy, novelty, randomness, or playing as a different character. We computed children's preference score for each variable by calculating a weighted average of their first and second choice preference (score = ⅔ × first + ⅓ × second). By including both responses, these results capture more information about children's preferences and thus strongly test the hypothesized condition effect. (Supplemental Materials: C shows similar results when considering only children's first choice).

Children's preferred game settings are shown in Fig. 2a. We modeled children's preference score using mixed effects linear regression with fixed effects of condition (0=Win, 1=Fun), variable type (0=win-relevant, 1=win-irrelevant), age (in months, z-scored), and their interactions, as well as random

intercepts for subjects and items. The best fit model included all main effects and two-way interactions (see Table S3 These results are consistent when looking at responses by individuals. A significant majority of children (67.5%, binomial p = .002 against chance of 50%) chose higher difficulty win-relevant settings when playing for fun than when playing to win. In contrast, on win-irrelevant variables only 56% of children chose higher settings when playing for fun than when playing to win (binomial p = .31).
We

.48], p = .009), with older children showing more sensitivity to condition. Nonetheless, even the youngest participants (exploratory analysis with n = 24 five and six-year-olds) were sensitive to condition, preferring easier win-relevant settings when playing to win than when playing for fun (d = 0.61, paired t(23) = 2.98, two-tailed p = .007).

We also found a significant age by variable type interaction (β = -0.08, 95% CI [-0.13, -0.03], p = .002; see Fig. S3a). In general, older children were more likely to choose harder win-relevant settings (r(78) = 0.25, 95% CI [0.03, 0.44], p = .028), but age did not predict win-irrelevant choices (r(78) = -0.05, 95% CI [-0.27, 0.17], p = .67).

div.head: D R A F T
div.p: "Does it matter" judgments

We modeled children's relevance judgments using mixed effects logistic regression with fixed effects of condition, variable type, age, as well as random intercepts for subjects and items. The best fit model included all main effects and interactions among fixed effects (including the three-way interaction; see Table S4 for details).

Children's explicit judgments about whether each game setting mattered ( Fig. 3a) .54], p = .001), but not when playing for fun (r(78) = -.10, p = .37). Age did not predict relevance judgments of win-irrelevant variables in either condition (r Win (78) = -0.16, p = .15; r Fun (78) = -0.07, p = .53). These developmental trends are shown in Fig. S3b.

div.head: Choice of game
div.p: At the end of the study, we asked children whether they would rather play for fun, or try to win.
Participants were evenly split between playing for fun (43%) and playing to win (53%, binomial p = .26;
one child excluded for failing to respond). These results suggest that both fun and winning are valuable

goals for children. In an exploratory analysis, we examined if children's game preference would explain variability in their responses to earlier questions. However, adding game preference as a covariate to the earlier regression models did not significantly improve model fit for predicting either children's preferred game settings ( 2 (1) = 3.06, p = .08) or their relevance judgments ( 2 (1) = 0.01, p = .93) (see Supplemental Materials: D for details). Thus, children did not choose harder settings when playing for fun just because they thought fun is more rewarding than winning, or judge that win-relevant variables matter just because they prefer winning to having fun. Instead, the differences in their choices reflect differences in the underlying motivational context, showing both that children can reason accurately and explicitly about factors influencing the probability of winning and that there is an important sense in which playing for fun goes beyond playing to win.
div.formula: D R A F T Experiment 2
div.p: In Experiment 1, children preferred easier win-relevant settings when playing to win than when playing for fun. They also judged that win-relevant variables were important when playing to win but not when playing for fun. In contrast, children were less likely to distinguish win-irrelevant variables by condition:

children chose similar win-irrelevant settings in both conditions for two out of four variables, and judged that all four win-irrelevant variables were not important under both motivations. These findings are compatible with the hypothesis that children can flexibly reason about and manipulate tasks along multiple dimensions to suit different motivations. However, there are at least two limitations. First, the within-subjects design may artificially inflate condition differences: because children heard both options, they might have assumed that they were supposed to respond differently across conditions for all questions. Second, participants lacked personal experience with Beach Bowling prior to making their judgments. Experiment 2 addresses both concerns: it uses a between-subjects design in which children try the activity (with all settings at "medium") before responding. Thus, children are familiarized with the task mechanics, and we can analyze how children in different conditions would modify the game relative to this common baseline.

div.head: Participants
div.p: We recruited n = 44 English-speaking children (27 female) aged 5 to 10 years (M = 7.19, SD = 1.39) from the same sites as in Experiment 1. Participants were randomly assigned to condition (between-subjects;
Win n=24, Fun n=20). Four additional children were excluded for disinterest or asking to stop the activity.
The sample size was chosen based on the effect size observed in pilot data with n = 15 participants.

div.head: Materials and procedure
div.p: Our procedure complies with all relevant ethical regulations and was approved by the Committee for the Protection of Human Subjects at [omitted for peer review] where the study was conducted. Participants and/or guardians provided informed consent. We used the materials from Experiment 1 and made two key
changes to the procedure. First, after an experimenter demonstrated Beach Bowling, but before any variables were introduced, children completed three tosses themselves, with all "medium" settings.

Second, we used a between-subjects design. After a child had completed three tosses, Experimenter 1 told them the "rules" of the condition to which they were randomly assigned: "Now that you know how to play Beach Bowling, let me tell you something else. There's actually a rule for this game. The rule of this game is that you need to have as much fun as you can / knock down all the blocks to win stickers."

Experimenter 1 then introduced the critical task: "You get to make some choices about how to set up the game in order to have as much fun as you can / knock down all the blocks to win stickers. Ok?" The remainder was identical with Experiment 1, but children were asked only about the condition to which they had been assigned. Children in Experiment 2 thus answered 24 questions compared to 48 in Experiment 1.

div.head: Game Setting Choices
div.p: Children's preferred game settings are shown in Fig. 2b. As in Experiment 1, we calculated each participant's preference score as a weighted average of their first and second choices for each variable, before aggregating by variable type (win-relevant or irrelevant) within each condition. We modeled children's preference score using mixed effects linear regression with fixed effects of condition, variable type, age, and their interactions, as well as random intercepts for subjects and items. Model comparison using likelihood ratio tests found that none of the interaction terms involving age improved model fit, so D R A F T these were excluded from the final model. The best fit model therefore included all main effects and the interaction of condition by variable type (see Table S4).
As predicted, and replicating Experiment 1, children's preferences differed between the two

div.head: Preference shift from baseline attempt
div.p: In Experiment 2, children played the game at "medium" settings before being assigned to a condition and answering questions. Thus, we can look at how children's first choice preference compares to their baseline experience, and how this shift might differ by condition. 1 We computed a "shift" score for each variable, defined as the change from baseline setting ("2") to children's first choice preference. This score ranged from -1 to +1. For example, a child who chose the highest difficulty setting ("3") as their first response would be coded as making a +1 shift from baseline.

div.head: D R A F T
div.p: Overall, children chose the lowest setting as their first choice more often when playing to win (M Win = 3.12 of 8 variables) than when playing for fun (M Fun = 1.65;  2 (5) = 17.1, p = .004). Critically, these choices differed by variable type. On win-relevant variables, children preferred significantly easier settings than baseline when playing to win (mean shift = -0.47, t(23) = -5.48, two-tailed p < .001) but significantly harder settings than baseline when playing for fun (mean shift = +0.3, t(19) = 2.90, p = .009), reflecting a strong condition effect (t(38.8) = 5.72, two-tailed p < .001). On win-irrelevant variables however, children preferred significantly higher settings than baseline in both conditions (mean shift in Win = +0.38, t(23) = 6.04, p < .001; Fun = +0.21, t(19) = 2.90, p = .009), with no difference in shift magnitude across conditions (t(39.8) = 1.78, p = .083). In summary, these results replicate Experiment 1 in finding that children selectively modify win-relevant variables to optimize for ease when playing to win but not when playing for fun, but treat win-irrelevant variables similarly in both conditions.

"Does it matter" judgments Children in Experiment 2 also recognized that the importance of win-relevant and win-irrelevant variables depends on the game condition (see Fig. 3). The best fit mixed-effects logistic regression model predicting children's relevance judgments in Experiment 2 included fixed effects of condition, variable type, age, and all two-way and three-way interactions, as well as random intercepts for subjects and items (see Table S5).

A significant condition by variable type interaction (β = 1.56, OR = 4.78, 95% CI [1.19, 19.22], p = .03) revealed that when playing to win, children judged win-relevant variables (M Win,Win-relevant = 62%) to matter more than win-irrelevant variables (M Win,Win-irrelevant = 31%; d = 0.84, paired t(22)= -3.37, p = .003).

Conversely, children in the Fun condition judged all variables to be unimportant, with no difference between win-relevant (M Fun,Win-relevant =19%) and win-irrelevant variables (M Fun,Win-irrelevant =16%; d = 0.08, paired t(19)= 0.33, p = .75).

Replicating Experiment 1, here we also found a significant three-way interaction between age, condition, and variable type (β = 2.65, OR = 14.16, 95% CI [2.91, 68.95], p = .001). Older children were less likely to respond that win-irrelevant variables are important when playing to win (r(22) = -0.41, 95%

the likelihood of winning. Age was not significantly correlated with judgments of win-relevant variables (see Fig. S4), though the trends are consistent with an increased appreciation that win-relevant variables matter more when playing to win than playing for fun.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: This study investigated the structure of play by examining how differences in motivation affect children's choices in a game design task. In particular, we sought to investigate: 1) how sensitive children are to the factors that affect winning a game (according to the extrinsically specified rules of the game); and 2) the ways in which their decision-making when playing to win differs from their decision making when playing the game simply to have fun. We thus introduced children to a novel task that could be modified along eight dimensions. We then asked children to choose the best settings for these dimensions to either have fun or to win the game, a contrast we manipulated both within subjects (Experiment 1) and between subjects (Experiment 2). In both experiments, children chose easier settings for win-relevant factors-those affecting the likelihood of winning-when playing to win than when playing to have fun.

In Experiment 1, we found no differences across conditions for win-irrelevant dimensions as a whole (though children chose lower settings when playing to win for two of four win-irrelevant dimensions), and no differences for win-irrelevant dimensions (collectively or individually) in Experiment 2. In addition, children in both experiments judged that win-relevant variables mattered in the Win Condition but that no variables mattered in the Fun Condition. Finally, Experiment 2 compared children's choices to a baseline version of the game and showed that children preferred higher than baseline settings for all factors when playing for fun, while preferring lower settings for win-relevant factors and higher settings for win-irrelevant factors when playing to win.

For our first question, these results suggest that children are explicitly sensitive to which variables are win-relevant. More importantly, children also preferentially manipulate win-relevant variables as D R A F T motivations change, while generally preferring the same settings for win-irrelevant variables across conditions. One caveat is that children in Experiment 1 showed mixed responses on win-irrelevant factors, though the within-subjects design of Experiment 1 may have artificially exaggerated differences between conditions. It is best to consider these results alongside the between-subjects results of Experiment 2, where children's judgments about all factors were more consistent with the idea that children understand how well each feature fits different motivations and choose accordingly. The relative lack of differences across conditions for win-irrelevant variables could be partly due to lack of attention to the relevant variables, leading to struggles in judging the appropriate changes. This difficulty could explain why an effect for win-irrelevant variables only appears in Experiment 1, where the contrast between conditions was more evident. This scenario seems unlikely, however, given that children in both experiments judged that win-relevant factors mattered for winning but not for having fun, and that win-irrelevant factors mattered in neither condition. Overall, our results suggest that children can recognize which task factors are relevant in a given motivational context and set them accordingly.

In answer to our second question, our results suggest that playing for fun is distinct from playing to win in that children make different decisions across conditions and judge the importance of win-relevant variables differently across conditions. We have not shown, however, that any particular optimization occurs when playing for fun. Looking at win-relevant variables, our results are consistent with children optimizing for ease, efficiency, and achievement when playing to win and simply relaxing the optimization when playing for fun. Nonetheless, challenge strongly predicts task enjoyment, even more so than skill, in play-like activities in adults (Abuhamdeh & Csikszentmihalyi, 2012), so it seems likely to us that children are challenge-seeking in some way when playing for fun. Looking at win-irrelevant variables, children generally chose elevated settings both when playing for fun and when playing to win. Because these features were not related to winning in any meaningful way, children must have been intrinsically motivated to choose these settings. 2 Thus, while children's choices during play can
be modified by a desire to win or have fun, they are also strongly driven by a consistent (but as yet, largely unspecified) set of intrinsic motivations.

Continuing our discussion of win-irrelevant variables, we found that across experiments and conditions, children chose high levels of randomness, novelty, and autonomy. Playing as a different character was the only win-irrelevant variable where children generally preferred the lowest setting (i.e.,

to play as themselves instead of dressing up). This finding is curious because pretense is important to play in many cultures (Boyette, 2016;Carlson et al., 1998;Taylor & Carlson, 2000). Perhaps pretense is sufficiently demanding that adding it to an unfamiliar and complex task is overwhelming. It could also be that pretense adds little value to our task's salient goal of knocking down blocks, compared to other contexts where pretense is itself the core activity. Moreover, pretend play is more prevalent in younger children, especially preschoolers, and the school-aged children in this study may see the game's rules as sufficient pretense on their own (Taylor, 1999), or may have found the particular costumes too "juvenile".
Whatever the case, further studies can explore additional win-irrelevant dimensions to better understand what children optimize for when playing for fun.

Our findings leave open several other avenues for future research. First, it is an interesting open question whether children, who differentiate "play for fun" and "play to win" in this paradigm, might also differentiate both conditions from "playing to learn" or even simply "playing". Play comprises an extraordinarily flexible class of behaviors, and comparing the various motivations children bring to play may help better understand its underlying structure. Second, it would be interesting to examine how children's challenge-seeking for fun is affected by individual differences in in persistence (Leonard et al., 2021; J. (Jenny) Wang & Bonawitz, 2022), grit (Duckworth et al., 2007), mindset (Dweck, 2006), or social inference (Bass et al., 2021). Third, our experiments offer insight into children's judgments of fun, but did not explicitly assess children's opinions of how much fun each feature setting might be and intentionally did not measure children's experience of fun. People necessarily make decisions based on what they think will happen, rather than based on what actually does happen. Additional studies might investigate how children's experiences of fun shape their beliefs about what they expect to be fun-perhaps by examining how children's play judgments change over time. Finally, while we found a weak correlation between age and difficulty preferences, future work might explore potential developmental changes in children's play decisions, including how they estimate and weigh task difficulty into their play decisions, especially in novel tasks where the relations between environment variables, player skills, and the likelihood of different outcomes can be more opaque or complex.

While we have focused on interactions between motivation and goal selection in this work, these are not the only factors driving decision-making. Among other things, people must balance ends and means to create goals which they can accomplish while also seeking means that make it possible to accomplish valuable goals. These interactions pose a challenging learning problem, and it remains poorly understood how children solve it. In particular, we do not know how children learn about the space of possible goals, which goals are most appropriate to a particular intrinsic motivation, how to value individual goals, or how to judge a goal's feasibility.

We speculate, however, that this learning problem is deeply related to play. In particular, children in Experiment 2 reliably chose harder than baseline settings for all variables when playing for fun. While play has been notoriously difficult to define and explain (Chu & Schulz, 2020;Rubin et al., 1983;Zosh et al., 2018), its challenge-seeking orientation-the willingness to relax commitments to ease, efficiency, and achievement-may help children learn the complex relationships involved in effective decision making. For example, play may be primarily about proposing goals and pursuing them to learn about the structure of problems and their solutions (Chu & Schulz, 2023a). If so, children may pursue goals with a problem-directed curiosity, focused on exploring what kinds of problems can be posed and how they can be solved. In this case, challenge-seeking may be a particularly easy method for devising new goals.

Alternatively, children at play may express competence-directed curiosity, placing more emphasis on learning about their own abilities than about the structure of the environment (White, 1959). In this case, challenge-seeking may be a particularly efficient way for children to learn and extend the limits of their

competence. Similarly, play may optimize for empowerment gain. 3 Empowerment (Klyubin et al., 2005;Salge et al., 2013) and related measures (Liljeholm, 2018) assess how well the effects of an agent's actions can be predicted from the actions themselves; empowerment gain measures improvements in an agent's ability to control the world through their actions. In this case, children might seek challenges to improve their ability to control the world. These alternatives are neither exhaustive nor mutually exclusive; play may instead be better formulated in terms of other frameworks such as optimizing free energy (Buckley et al., 2017;Friston et al., 2006), pursuing novelty (Stanley & Lehman, 2015;R. Wang et al., 2020), or exploring rare action-state combinations (Ramírez-Ruiz et al., 2024). Future studies can explore all these hypotheses using the approach we took here. Asking children to make choices about tasks along dimensions separating these hypotheses, perhaps with a revised version of the paradigm used here, would both test various theories of play in a fine-grained way and illuminate how play relates to decision making more broadly. More generally, because our paradigm can be adapted to offer choices along a wide variety of dimensions, it offers a well-controlled and adaptable window into how intrinsic motivations-typically opaque-affect everyday decision making.

Continuing to explore the intrinsic motivations behind play through these and other sorts of experiments would also be valuable because of the critical role play has throughout developmental and educational psychology. Many experiments in developmental psychology are framed as games for children to play. If play draws on specific intrinsic motivations that affect goal selection and other aspects of decision making, having a detailed understanding of those effects would help experimenters to both interpret their results and to design experiments compensating for those effects. Similarly, guided play-which marries children's impulses toward free play with scaffolding toward specific learning goals-has emerged in educational psychology as a powerful learning tool (Weisberg et al., 2013(Weisberg et al., , 2016.

div.head: D R A F T
div.p: Better understanding how the intrinsic motivations behind play affect decision making (Skene et al., 2022;Zosh et al., 2018) could make guided play an even more effective tool for educators.

Our work is one step toward understanding the complex dynamics of human decision making, especially in the context of play. Many issues remain open, such as: how people manage a much more complex set of motivations than those explored here; what the space of possible goals is like; and how adopting a goal affects other aspects of decision making. To answer these questions, we need to study decision making using a broader range of possible motivations and goals. Doing so is challenging, but will enable a better understanding of human action and of intelligent behavior. In other words, science can be hard, but it is possible both to win and to have fun doing it.
Competing Interests The authors declare none.
div.formula: D R A F T D R A F T D R A F T D R A F T D R A F T D R A F T D R A F T D R A F T 1
div.p: Supplemental Materials for Fun isn't easy: Children selectively manipulate task difficulty when "playing for fun" vs. "playing to win"

In section (A) we provide more details on the materials used and the design of the task. In subsequent sections, we report preregistered exploratory analyses investigating the effects of condition order in die (7.5cm x 8cm x 7.5cm) painted white with a large dot on each side corresponding to one of each of the 6 colors of the rubber spots; and 3 laminated plastic spinners (see Fig. 1a in main text). Table S1: Game setting variables and options

As described in the main text, we designed four win-relevant variables which affected the likelihood of knocking down blocks, and four win-irrelevant variables that did not affect game difficulty but are common features of children's everyday play, such as tossing a dice to determine turn order or dressing up as a make-believe character. Here, we detail what the three choice options were for each variable. In Experiment 1, we manipulated game condition (Win or Fun) within subjects, and counterbalanced across participants which condition was presented first. We found that children who first answered questions in the Win condition tended to choose slightly higher game settings (M=2.03, SD = 0.29) than children who first answered questions in the Fun condition (M=1.93, SD= 0.25; paired t(79) = 2.27, p = 0.026). However, in both counterbalanced orders we found results consistent with the main finding reported in the main text: children's preferred game settings differed by condition, depending on variable type (see Fig. S2).

div.head: Choice options
div.p: To quantitatively test these observations, we conducted a linear mixed effects regression analysis predicting the difference in average choices by condition (Fun -Win) for each order (Fun or Win first) and variable type (win-relevant or win-irrelevant), with random by-subject intercepts. We found a significant interaction between order and variable type ( 2 (1) = 7.07, p = .008) and a main effect of variable type ( 2 (1) = 14.64, p < .001), but no main effect of order (p = 0.85). Specifically, children who first answer questions for the Fun condition showed a condition effect for both variable types, choosing harder win-relevant settings (t(156) = 4.21, p < .001) and higher levels of win-irrelevant settings
div.formula: D R A F T D R A F T
div.p: As described in the Main Text, we ran exploratory regression analyses to examine developmental trends in children's responses. We focus on potential interactions between age (in months), condition, and variable type. Age was standardized into z-scores to aid model convergence. Below, we visualize these developmental trends, and report the best-fit model estimates for each response measure (preference score and relevance judgments). Fig. S3. Developmental trends in Experiment 1. Each point represents responses from one participant (n=88), with best-fit regression lines and 95% confidence intervals. Asterisks indicate significant age effects for each combination of condition and variable type. (a) Children's preferred game settings by condition (Win / Fun) and variable type (Win-relevant / -irrelevant; both factors within-subjects). For win-relevant variables, children preferred harder settings when playing for fun than when playing to win, with older children showing a stronger preference. For win-irrelevant variables however, children across the age range had similar preferences whether playing for fun or playing to win. (b) Proportion of variables judged to matter for the present game, by condition and variable type. There was a significant three-way interaction of condition, variable type, and age. Older children were more likely to judge that win-relevant variables matter when playing to win.

div.head: Experiment 1
div.p: Preferred game settings

We ran a mixed effects linear regression analysis predicting children's preference score for each variable from age, condition (Win or Fun), and variable type (win-relevant or win-irrelevant), with random intercepts for subject and item. The best fit model included all two-way interactions; adding a three-way interaction did not significantly improve model fit ( 2 (1) = 1.76, p = .18). Table S2 reports model estimates. To assess possible developmental trends in children' judgment of which variable matters for either condition, we ran a mixed effects logistic regression analysis predicting children's binary responses (0 = does not matter, 1 = matters) for each variable from age, condition, and variable type (win-relevant or win-irrelevant), with random intercepts for subject and item. Model comparison by likelihood ratio tests found that the best fit model was the full model with all interactions. Specifically, the three-way age by condition and variable type interaction significantly improved model fit ( 2 (1) = 16.8, p < .001). S4. Developmental trends in Experiment 2. Each point represents responses from one participant, with best-fit regression lines and 95% confidence intervals. Asterisks indicate significant age effects for each combination of condition and variable type. (a) Children's preferred game settings by condition (Win / Fun, between-subjects) and variable type (Win-relevant / -irrelevant, within-subjects). For win-relevant variables, children preferred harder settings when playing for fun than when playing to win, with older children showing a stronger preference. For win-irrelevant variables however, age did not affect preferences in either condition. (b) Proportion of variables judged to matter for the present game, by condition and variable type. However, older children were more likely to judge that win-relevant variables matter when playing to win.

div.head: D R A F T
div.formula: D R A F T 8 Experiment 2 Fig.

div.head: Preferred game settings
div.p: Preregistered analysis. In Experiment 2, because condition was manipulated between-subjects, we tested the correlation between age and preferred variable choices (weighted average) for each condition separately, instead of computing a condition difference score (see Fig. S4).

div.head: D R A F T 9
div.p: In the Win condition, older children chose higher settings overall (r(22) = 0.49, p = .01). Looking within each variable type, older children preferred harder settings on win-relevant variables (r(22) = 0.54, p = .006) but chose similar settings as younger children on win-irrelevant variables (r(22) = 0.016, p = 0.95). In contrast, age did not predict children's choices in the Fun condition, whether collapsing across all variables (r(18) = 0.17, p = .48) or for each variable type separately (win-relevant: r(18) = 0.015, p = 0.95; win-irrelevant: r(18) = 0.25, p = 0.29). These results are consistent with the significant three-way interaction of age by variable type and condition in a regression analysis (see "Exploratory regression analysis" to follow).

Exploratory regression analysis. We ran a linear mixed effects regression to assess potential interactions between age, condition, and variable type. This model included as predictors age (in months), condition, variable type, and their interactions, with a by-subject random intercept. The best fit model identified using likelihood ratio tests was the full model with all interaction terms (Table S4). Specifically, the three-way age by condition and variable type interaction significantly improved model fit over the model with only main effects ( 2 (4) = 46.3, p < .001) and also the model with two-way interactions ( 2 (1) = 4.58, p = .032).

When inspecting the simple slope of age for each combination of condition and variable type, we found that the only significant age trend was on win-relevant variables in the Win condition, with older children preferring more difficult settings (β age_z = 0.10, t(100) = 2.54, p = .01). In summary, these findings replicate the results reported in the main text. When controlling for age, children chose different settings on win-relevant variables depending on condition, but made similar choices on win-irrelevant variables in both conditions. We also assessed possible developmental trends in children' judgment of which variable matters.

We ran a mixed effects logistic regression analysis predicting children's binary responses (0 = does not matter, 1 = matters) for each variable from age, condition, and variable type (win-relevant or win-irrelevant), with random intercepts for subject and item. Model comparison by likelihood ratio tests found that the best fit model was the full model with all interactions. Specifically, the three-way age by condition and variable type interaction significantly improved model fit over the model with only main effects ( 2 (4) = 19.2, p < .001) and also the model with two-way interactions ( 2 (1) = 13.3, p < .001).

div.head: E: Analysis of Responses by Gender
div.p: In Experiment 1, we looked at responses from the 79 participants (out of 80) who provided a gender (45 male, 34 female). In Experiment 2, we looked at responses from all 44 participants (17 male, 27 female).
In summary, we did not find any evidence of gender effects on children's responses.

First, we looked at potential effects of gender on children's preferred game setting choices. In Experiment 1 there was no effect of gender on children's overall preference whether collapsed across conditions (t(66.1) = -0.88, p = 0.38) or within each condition (Win t(58.2) = -0.65, p = 0.52; Fun t(73.8) = -0.68, p = 0.5). In Experiment 2, we also found no gender differences in either condition (Win t(21.8) = 0.032, p = 0.97; Fun t(15.3) = -0.63, p = 0.54).

Next, we looked at gender effects on preferred game settings for win-relevant and win-irrelevant settings separately. We found no evidence for gender effects in either Experiment 1 (win-relevant t(63.2) D R A F T

Experiment 1 (B), as well as preregistered analyses of children's first-choice preferences (C), and the effects of age (D) and gender (E) on children's responses. A: Details of task design and materials

figure.head: Fig
figure.figDesc: . S1 shows the game set up. Materials included: a large bowling alley style "court" composed of interlocking foam mats (top portion 1.2m x 1.3m; bottom portion 2.7m x 1.7m) ; a plastic container (27cm x 18.5cm x 25cm decorated to resemble a treasure chest; 6 bean bags; 12 rubber swimming batons (6 yellow; 2 green; 2 yellow with flashing lights; 2 green with flashing lights); 3 blue polyester sunshades for infants decorated to resemble open-mouthed sharks; 6 yoga blocks (3 foam, 3 cork; all 13cm x 7cm x 22cm) covered in striped wrapping paper; 6 circular, multi-colored flat rubber spots (diameter 23cm) one

figure.head: Fig. S1 .

figure.figDesc: Photo of the experimental "Beach Bowling" task.

for details).First, we examine how children respond to condition and variable type. As predicted, children's preferences differed between the two conditions (β Fun-Win = 0.39, 95% CI [0.32, 0.46], p < .001). On average, children chose higher settings when playing for fun (M Fun =2.11, SD = 0.25) than when playing to win (M Win = 1.85, SD=0.23; Cohen's d = 0.82, paired t(79)=7.37, two-tailed p < .001). However, this condition difference was greater for win-relevant variables than win-irrelevant variables, as revealed by a significant condition by variable type interaction (β Fun*Win-irrelevant = -0.26, 95% CI [-0.36, -0.16], p < .001).On win-relevant variables, children chose higher difficulty settings when playing for fun (M Fun =2.06) than when playing to win (M Win =1.67; d = 0.73; paired t(79) = 6.51, two-tailed p < .001), with significant condition differences on all four win-relevant variables (ps < .001, paired two-tailed t-tests with Bonferroni correction). Children's choices also differed on win-irrelevant variables (d = 0.39, paired t(79)= 3.51, p < .001), though this was driven by a subset of variables. When setting up the game to maximize fun, compared to winning, children chose slightly higher levels of novelty (M Fun = 2.48, M Win = 2.15, t(79)

Comparing both conditions, children judged that win-relevant variables would matter more when playing to Win (M Win =57%) than when playing for Fun (M Fun =18%; d = 0.72, paired t(79)=7.52, p < .001), but they did not differentiate win-irrelevant variables by condition (paired t(79) = 0.52, p = .6). Altogether, children's explicit valuation of available game settings reflected their preferred game setting choices.

body.note: We preregistered an analysis predicting the direction and magnitude of shift in preferred setting given children's initial success at the game. However, constraints on camera positioning prevented us from coding how many blocks children hit during familiarization.

Children could be responding to a shared set of background extrinsic motivations, such as a belief that responding in a certain way might lead to praise. Given the relative diversity of children's potential expectations of experimenters and caretakers, however, it seems more likely to us that these results reflect intrinsic motivation.

Computational models of flow also rely on empowerment(Melnikoff et al., 2022), though the emphasis is less on gains in empowerment, and more on preexisting empowerment. These two proposals are perhaps complementary and compatible with recent theories of human life history(Gopnik, 2020): early gains in empowerment from play, or learning to identify opportunities for empowerment gain in play, may increase opportunities for flow later in life.

In the main text, we report an analysis of children's game setting choices by integrating their first and second choice preference for each variable. Here, we report the same analyses for Experiment 1 considering only children's first choice preference

analytic.title: On win-relevant variables, children chose more difficult settings when playing for fun than when playing to win (M Fun = 2.12, M Win = 1.51; d = 0.80, paired t(79) = 7.19, p < .001). For win-irrelevant variables, children's choices also differed by condition (M Fun = 2.24, M Win = 2.05; d = 0.39, paired t(79) = 3.49, p < .001), preferring higher levels of novelty and character when playing for fun than to win

monogr.title: Overall, children chose higher settings when playing for fun (M Fun =2.18) than when playing to win (M Win =1.78; d = 0.89, paired t(79) = 7.96, two-tailed p < .001)

biblStruct.note: Results for Experiment 2 have been reported in the main text
